Front: What is the difference between a parametric and nonparametric test?
Back: Nonparametric statistical procedures extend the reach of inference because they can be used when data is ranked, make few assumptions about the population, and address questions unrelated to parameters.

Front: What is technical analysis?
Back: This is an approach to valuation that involves forecasting the future direction of prices through the study of past market data and historical patterns (primarily related to price and volume).

Front: What are the assumptions that support technical analysis?
Back: The assumptions that predicate technical analysis include: prices move in trends; history repeats itself; and, prices already reflect all relevant information, i.e. fundamentals.

Front: What are the arguments against technical analysis?
Back: Arguments against technical analysis include: studies that show contradictory predictions among technical analysts; technical analysis is subject to the subjective methods of analysts; the EMH and random walk hypothesis contradict all the tenets of technical analysis; and, excessive charting allows any number of patterns to wrongly appear.

Front: What is rule-based trading?
Back: This is an approach involving technical analysis in which trades occur according to a defined set of rules, leaving minimal discretion. The theory is that patterns support the trading rules and that abiding by these rules will reduce the poor decisions that an investor might otherwise make.

Front: What is price elasticity of demand?
Back: This is the percentage change in quantity demanded per the percentage change in price of a commodity. It is a measure of how responsive quantity demanded is to price changes.

Front: What is cross elasticity of demand?
Back: This is the percentage change in quantity demanded for one good per a percentage change in price of another good. NLNWhen two goods are substitutes, the cross elasticity of demand will be positive; when the price of one good goes up, consumers will demand more of its substitute. NLNWhen two goods are complements, the cross elasticity of demand will be negative; as the price of one good goes up, consumers will demand less of its complement. NLNWhen two goods are independent, the cross elasticity of demand will be zero; a change in the price of the first good will have no effect on the quantity demanded of the second.

Front: What is income elasticity of demand?
Back: This is the percentage change in quantity demanded per a percentage change in income of people demanding the good. NLNA positive income elasticity of demand exists for normal goods. If income elasticity of demand for a product is less than 1, it is a necessity good. If the elasticity of demand is greater than 1, that product is a luxury good. NLNA negative income elasticity of demand exists for inferior goods. As consumer income increases, demand for inferior goods will fall, and consumers will choose more luxurious substitutes. NLNZero income elasticity of demand (or inelastic demand) exists for sticky goods, for which an increase in income is not associated with a change in the quantity demanded.

Front: What is an inferior good?
Back: When a reduction in household income results in an increase in demand for a product, that product is an inferior good. Examples of inferior goods include things like margarine and public transportation.

Front: What is the elasticity of supply?
Back: This is the percentage change in quantity supplied of a product per a percentage change in price of that product. It measures the sensitivity of supply to changes in price.

Front: Describe inelastic demand.
Back: Inelastic demand for a good (|E| < 1) exists when the percentage change in quantity demanded is smaller than the percentage change in price.

Front: Describe unit elastic demand.
Back: Unit elastic demand for a good (|E| = 1) exists when the percentage change in quantity demanded is equal to the percentage change in price.

Front: Describe elastic demand.
Back: Elastic demand for a good (|E| > 1) exists when the percentage change in quantity demanded is larger than the percentage change in price.

Front: Describe perfectly elastic demand and the corresponding demand curve.
Back: Perfectly elastic demand (|E| is undefined) exists when any increase in price, however small, will cause demand for the good to drop to zero. The corresponding demand curve is a horizontal straight line.

Front: Describe perfectly inelastic demand and the corresponding demand curve.
Back: Perfectly inelastic demand (|E| is 0) exists when changes in the price do not affect the quantity demanded of a good. The corresponding demand curve is a vertical straight line.

Front: What is the relation between price elasticity of demand and total revenue?
Back: If price elasticity of demand for an item is elastic, then consumers will spend more on an item when its price falls. Thus, total revenue would increase as prices fall. For inelastic demand, a price decrease will lead to lower total revenue. For unit elastic demand, changes in price will not affect total revenue.

Front: What is the rule of 70?
Back: The rule of 70 is a rule of thumb  for estimating the approximate number of years it will take for GDP to double given an expected growth rate: NLNThe approximate number of years to double is equal to 70 divided by the growth rate. NLNNote: this could apply to any scenario in which you want to estimate how long it will take for a value to double given an expected rate of change.

Front: What are the factors of production?
Back: The factors of production are:NLN1. LandNLN2. Capital goodsNLN3. LaborNLN4.Entrepreneurial ability

Front: What are the three social institutions critical to incentivizing economic growth?
Back: The three social institutions critical to incentivizing economic growth are:NLN1. MarketsNLN2. Property rightsNLN3. Monetary exchange

Front: What is physical capital?
Back: Physical capital is any non-human, non-money asset used in production.

Front: What is financial capital?
Back: Financial capital is the money used to purchase the means of production and business operation.

Front: What is the relation between demand for physical capital and demand for financial capital?
Back: A firm's demand for financial capital is dependent on its demand for physical capital. The amount of funding required is determined by the amount of purchases that need to be made in order to operate the business.

Front: What is economic rent?
Back: This is the excess payment to any factor of production above the amount required to employ it (and sustain it) in production.

Front: What is allocative efficiency?
Back: Allocative efficiency occurs when the limited resources of a firm are allocated to the “optimal mix” of commodities demanded by consumers. In a perfect market, allocative efficiency is reached when price is equal to marginal costs.

Front: What is marginal benefit?
Back: Marginal benefit is the additional benefit received when one more unit of a good is produced.

Front: What is marginal cost?
Back: Marginal costs are the additional costs incurred when one more unit of a good is produced.

Front: What is marginal utility?
Back: Marginal utility pertains to the incremental change in satisfaction to the consumer gained from an additional unit of a good or service. It is the amount of utility (which is quantifiable in economics) gained from the additional unit of consumption.

Front: What is the efficient quantity of production for a firm?
Back: The efficient quantity of production is where marginal cost equals marginal benefit.

Front: Describe consumer surplus.
Back: Consumer surplus is a measure of the welfare that people gain from the consumption of goods and services; it is the difference between the total amount that consumers are willing and able to pay for a good or service (as indicated by the demand curve) and the total amount that they actually do pay (the market equilibrium price for the product).

Front: Describe producer surplus.
Back: Producer surplus is a measure of the welfare that suppliers gain from selling goods and services; it is the difference between the total amount that producers are willing to receive for a good or service (as indicated by the supply curve) and the total amount that they actually do receive (the market equilibrium price for the product).

Front: Describe the relationship between consumer surplus, producer surplus, and equilibrium of supply and demand.
Back: When the quantity of production is at the point where supply equals demand (and the curves intercept), then both consumer surplus and producer surplus are maximized. NLNNote: Taxes, barriers to free trade, and other regulations can prevent a market from reaching this equilibrium, resulting in a deadweight loss and market inefficiency.

Front: Explain deadweight loss.
Back: Deadweight loss is fundamentally the costs to society created by inefficiency in the market, also known as allocative inefficiency. This exists when the free market equilibrium can't be reached; causes of deadweight loss can include monopoly pricing, externalities, taxes or subsidies, binding price ceilings or price floors. It is the consequential loss to consumer and producer surplus of not operating at the free market equilibrium.

Front: Describe the symmetry principle (a fairness principle).
Back: The symmetry principle asserts that equal opportunity defeats basic equality. NLNThe two relevant rules are: NLN1. Governments must recognize and protect private property. NLN2. Private property must be given from one party to another only voluntarily.

Front: Describe the effects and inefficiencies of rent ceilings in the housing sector.
Back: A rent ceiling is an example of a price ceiling; it is a government regulation that makes it illegal to charge more than a specified rent for housing. The impact of a rent ceiling depends on whether it is imposed at a level above or below the free market equilibrium price. Rent ceilings above the equilibrium price have no market impact. NLNFor rent ceilings below the equilibrium price, the quantity of units provided is limited to where marginal cost is equal to the rent ceiling (adjusted marginal benefit). Both consumer surplus and producer surplus shrink; deadweight loss arises, and resources are lost in search activity and evading the rent ceiling law (through black markets). Rent ceilings create shortages and oftentimes cause people to pay more rent than if the market were allowed to operate freely.

Front: Describe the effects and inefficiencies of a minimum wage above the equilibrium wage.
Back: Minimum wage is an example of a price floor. It is a government regulation that forces firms to pay no less than a specified amount to labor. When minimum wage levels are below the market equilibrium, there is no impact. The market will bid wages higher than the minimum wage. NLNWhen minimum wage levels are above the market equilibrium, the quantity of labor demanded is less than at market equilibrium. Consumer and producer surplus shrinks as deadweight loss arises, and resources are lost in job search. NLNMinimum wage regulations create labor surplus and thus may hurt the very people they are supposed to help; minimum wage also forces people to spend more time searching for work and may create a black market for work at less than the minimum wage.

Front: Explain the impact of taxes on supply, demand, and market equilibrium.
Back: Taxes decrease the quantity produced, because they raise the price for consumers and lower the price received by sellers. The loss to consumer surplus is allocated to deadweight loss and tax revenue. NLNNote: whether the tax is paid by the seller or the consumer depends on the elasticity of demand and the elasticity of supply.

Front: What is tax incidence and how is it affected by supply and demand elasticities?
Back: Tax incidence is the division of a tax burden between the buyer and the seller of a good. For a given elasticity of supply, the more inelastic the demand, the larger the share of tax paid by the buyer. For a given elasticity of demand, the more inelastic the supply, the larger the share of tax paid by the seller. NLNWhen demand is perfectly inelastic, the buyer pays the entire tax. When demand is perfectly elastic, the seller pays the entire tax.

Front: What is a subsidy?
Back: A subsidy is a form of financial assistance paid by the government to a producer (or economic sector).

Front: Describe the impact of subsidies on supply, demand, and market equilibrium.
Back: A subsidy increases supply (moves the supply curve to the right) and increases the quantity demanded (along the demand curve). At the new equilibrium, marginal cost (on the original/true supply curve) exceeds marginal benefit (on the demand curve) and a deadweight loss arises due to overproduction.

Front: What is a quota?
Back: A production quota is an upper limit to the quantity of production in a specified period.

Front: Describe the impact of quotas on supply, demand, and market equilibrium.
Back: A quota limits the quantity produced and consumed. In the new equilibrium, marginal cost is less than marginal benefit, and a deadweight loss results from underproduction.

Front: What is opportunity cost?
Back: Opportunity cost is the value of the next best alternative action forgone when making a decision.

Front: What are the different types of opportunity cost?
Back: The tow types of opportunity costs are: NLN1. Explicit costs. NLN2. Implicit costs.

Front: What is technological efficiency?
Back: A firm exhibits technological efficiency relative to other firms when it produces a given output using the least amount of inputs.

Front: What is economic efficiency?
Back: A firm exhibits economic efficiency relative to other firms when it produces a given output at the smallest per-unit cost.

Front: What is a command system?
Back: A command system is a method of organization in which production is managed according to the managerial hierarchy. Orders come down through the chain of command, and information is communicated back up to managers, who make most of the decisions.

Front: What is an incentive system?
Back: An incentive system is method of aligning compensation to the goals and objectives of the firm and/or divisions of the firm. Thus, employees are incentivized to perform in a manner that rewards both the firm and themselves.

Front: What is the principle-agent problem, and what steps can be taken to reduce it?
Back: The principle-agent problem describes the difficulty in aligning the incentives of managers with the goals of shareholders. For instance in large organizations, the interests of management (job preservation and compensation) diverge from the interests of owners/shareholders (maximization of firm value). A common interpretation of the problem is that managers are incentivized to achieve short-term gains instead of maximizing firm value in the long run. NLNThree ways of attempting to reduce the principle-agent problem are: NLN1. Ownership – Assigning some form of ownership to management and employees. NLN2. Incentive Pay – Compensating management and employees based on performance. NLN3. Long-Term Contracts – This ties the long-term compensation of managers and workers (agents) to the success of the owners of the firm (principals).

Front: Describe the different types of business organization.
Back: The three main types of business organizations are: NLN1. Proprietorship – a business with a sole owner who faces unlimited liability for the firm's debts and obligations. NLN2. Partnership – a business with two or more owners who face unlimited liability. Income flows to the partners according to each person's proportion of ownership. NLN3. Corporation – a business owned by stockholders, whose liability is legally limited to the amount that they invested. A corporation is a legal entity that pays income taxes. Stockholders pay capital gains taxes.

Front: Describe the four market types.
Back: The four market types are: NLN1. Perfect competition is a market where there are many firms, each selling an identical product, and many buyers. Also, there are no restrictions to the entry of new firms, and all sellers and buyers are well-informed. NLN2. Monopolistic competition is a market in which many firms compete by making slightly differentiated products. NLN3. Oligopoly is a market structure in which a small number of firms compete, each producing a differentiated product. There tends to be restrictions to the entry of new firms in this type of market. NLN4. Monopoly is a market structure comprised of one firm producing a product with no close substitutes and in which the firm is protected by a barrier to the entry of new firms (by legal right, economies of scale, etc.)

Front: What is the four-firm concentration ratio?
Back: The four-firm concentration ratio is the market share, as a percentage, of the four largest firms in the industry.

Front: What is the four-firm concentration ratio in a market experiencing perfect competition?
Back: A perfectly competitive market will have a four-firm ratio close to 0.

Front: What does a four-firm ratio of less than 40% indicate about the given market?
Back: A four-firm ratio of less than 40% indicates the market is competitive.

Front: What is the four-firm concentration ratio in an oligopoly?
Back: An oligopoly has a four-firm ratio greater than 60%.

Front: What does a four-firm ratio of 100% indicate about the given market?
Back: A four-firm ratio of 100% exists for a monopoly.

Front: What is the Herfindahl-Hirschman Index?
Back: The HHI is the sum of the squared market shares of the 50 largest firms in the market.

Front: What does a Herfindahl-Hirschman Index of less than 1,000 indicate about the given market?
Back: A HHI index of less than 1,000 indicates the market is very competitive.

Front: What is the Herfindahl-Hirschman Index range for a moderately competitive market?
Back: The HHI index for a moderately competitive market is between 1,000 – 1,800.

Front: What does a Herfindahl-Hirschman Index of greater than 1,800 indicate about the given market?
Back: A HHI index of greater than 1,800 indicates the market is uncompetitive.

Front: What is the Herfindahl-Hirschman Index value for a monopoly?
Back: The HHI index for a monopoly 10,000.

Front: What does it mean when a market coordinates production?
Back: This means that each input and/or division of labor is bought (or rented) separately and at market value in order to produce a good or service. In contrast, firms coordinate production by owning the inputs and capital and employing the labor, producing a good or service internally.

Front: Firms are often more efficient than markets in coordinating economic activity for what 4 reasons?
Back: A firm is more efficient than markets at coordinating economic activity because they can achieve: NLN1. Lower transaction costs. NLN2. Economies of scale. NLN3. Economies of scope. NLN4. Economies of team production.

Front: What are transaction costs?
Back: Transaction costs are costs that arise from making an economic exchange. It includes search and information costs incurred in finding sellers of a good and those with the lowest prices, etc. Bargaining costs are also a part of transaction costs, as are the policing and enforcement costs required to ensure that all terms of an agreement are fulfilled.

Front: What are economies of scale?
Back: Economies of scale exist when the cost of producing a good falls as more of that good is produced.

Front: What are economies of scope?
Back: Economies of scope exist for a firm when it can apply its specialized and often expensive resources (both human and industrial capital) to produce a range of goods and services. Thus, that firm can provide a breadth of goods and services to its clients.

Front: What are economies of team production?
Back: Economies of team production arise when individuals specialize in mutually supportive tasks as part of a production group, or team.

Front: Describe the relation between total product of labor, marginal product of labor, and average product of labor.
Back: Total product of labor is the quantity produced, and it is a function of labor and capital. The marginal product of labor is the additional quantity produced when expanding labor input alone by one unit. The average product of labor is total product of labor divided by amount of labor used.

Front: How does marginal product of labor relate to increasing and decreasing marginal returns?
Back: Increasing marginal returns exist when the marginal product of labor is positive. Decreasing marginal returns exist when the marginal product of labor is negative.

Front: How does the average product of labor relate to increasing and decreasing marginal returns?
Back: Increasing marginal returns exist when the average product of labor decreases per additional unit of labor used.

Front: Explain the relation between total cost, marginal cost, and average cost. How do the curves look?
Back: Marginal cost is the change in total cost required to produce one more unit of output. Average costs are the costs per unit of total production. NLNThe total cost curve is highest; below it is the average cost curve which is U-shaped. The marginal cost curve is lowest, also U-shaped, and it crosses the average cost curve upward at the minimum average cost.

Front: What are diseconomies of scale?
Back: Diseconomies of scale are forces that cause larger firms to produce goods and services at increasing costs per unit. It is theoretically the result of symptoms such as, but not limited to: office politics, duplication of effort, slow response time, cannibalization, public and government opposition, and so on.

Front: Differentiate between market and firm demand curves in a perfectly competitive market.
Back: The demand curve facing the whole market is conventionally downward-facing. The demand curve facing a firm, itself, in a perfectly competitive market is perfectly elastic and flat, and the price is the equilibrium price determined by the market.

Front: What is the profit maximizing (loss minimizing) output for a perfectly competitive firm?
Back: The profit maximizing, or loss minimizing, output for a perfectly competitive firm is that level of production where marginal revenue is equal to price.

Front: Describe a perfectly competitive firm's short-run supply curve.
Back: The supply curve is the marginal cost curve at and above the minimum average variable cost curve. That is, it is the portion of the marginal cost curve above the shut-down point.

Front: Explain the impact of changes in demand, entry and exit of firms, and changes in plant size on long-run equilibrium in a perfectly competitive market.
Back: Changes in demand will shift the demand curve, and firms will enter or exit the industry until the supply curve shifts to the extent that equilibrium is reached at the original price (where each individual firm is only making a normal profit). The entry and exit of firms, or changes in plant size will facilitate the move towards long-run equilibrium.

Front: What is the relation between marginal revenue and the elasticity of demand facing a monopoly?
Back: Marginal revenue is positive if demand is elastic and negative when demand is inelastic.

Front: What is price discrimination?
Back: This is when a firm is able to sell identical goods at different prices to customers, so that customers willing to pay more will pay more. Price discrimination results leads to a loss in consumer surplus and a gain in producer surplus.

Front: Describe monopoly price-setting strategies.
Back: Unlike a perfectly competitive firm, a monopoly can adjust the market price for its product, and it produces at a price and quantity on along the downward-sloping demand curve. However, just like a perfectly competitive firm, its optimal pricing decision should equate the marginal cost (MC) with the marginal revenue (MR) of production.

Front: How do you determine the profit a monopoly is making?
Back: This is the difference between price and average cost, times the quantity of production.

Front: What is the role of deadweight in a monopoly?
Back: The deadweight loss exists because a monopoly will price its product on the demand curve above the equilibrium price. The decrease in consumer surplus is larger than the increase in producer surplus, and the potential surplus that went neither to the monopolist or to consumers is the deadweight loss.

Front: What is rent-seeking?
Back: Rent seeking is the effort of a firm to establish itself as a monopoly, requiring the inefficient expenditure of resources and time.

Front: What is the profit maximizing (loss-minimizing) output under monopolistic competition and oligopoly?
Back: The profit maximizing price and output will always be where marginal cost equals marginal revenue, unless the firm is operating at a loss and is not a going concern, in which case it should leave the market entirely.

Front: What is the long-run economic profit for firms in monopolistic competition?
Back: The long run economic profit for firms in monopolistic competition is zero. This is because firms will enter the market to divide economic profits until they no longer exist.

Front: How efficient is monopolistic competition?
Back: A monopolistically competitive firm generally produces less output and charges a higher price than would be the case for a perfectly competitive firm. As long as the price per unit of product is higher than the marginal cost of production, the firm is not efficient. The degree of inefficiency of the market is determined by the elasticity of the demand curve. The more elastic the demand curve facing a monopolistically competitive firm, the more efficient is the market.

Front: Explain the importance of innovation, product development, advertising, and branding under monopolistic competition.
Back: Innovation, product development, advertising and branding are all tools that firms use to differentiate their product in a monopolistically competitive market.

Front: Explain the kinked demand curve model under an oligopoly.
Back: The demand curve is kinked because any increase above a certain price P would bring a big decrease in quantity sold, as the firm's competitors would steal market share at price P. At the same time, if a firm were to decrease prices below price P, this would bring about a relatively small increase in quantity sold because competitors would also lower prices.

Front: What is the Prisoners' Dilemma?
Back: The Prisoner's Dilemma is a fundamental problem in game theory, used to indicate the decision-making process for firms in an oligopoly as they set production levels and forecast profits.

Front: What is derived demand?
Back: This is when the demand for one good or service occurs because it is a factor of production for another. Therefore, the change in demand for the finished product, and consequent change in production, will change the derived demand for the input.

Front: What is the difference between marginal revenue and marginal revenue product (MRP)?
Back: Marginal revenue product is the increase in revenue per unit increase in a variable input of production. Marginal revenue is the increase in revenue per unit increase in the quantity produced.

Front: How does marginal revenue product (MRP) determine the demand for labor and the wage rate?
Back: To achieve maximum profit, firms will hire workers up to the point where marginal revenue product (MRP) is equal to the wage rate; therefore, if MRP increases, demand for labor increases and bids up the wage rate. Conversely, if MRP decreases, so does the demand for labor and the equilibrium wage rate.

Front: What factors change the demand for labor?
Back: Three factors affect the demand for labor: NLN1. the price of the firm's output NLN2. other factor prices NLN3. technology

Front: What factors determine the elasticity of market demand for labor?
Back: Three primary factors affect the demand for labor: NLN1. the labor intensity of the production process NLN2. the elasticity of demand for the product NLN3. the substitutability of capital for labor

Front: What factors determine the supply of labor?
Back: The key factors that affect the supply of labor are: NLN1. growth in the adult population NLN2. technological change and capital accumulation.

Front: Explain the difference between physical capital and financial capital.
Back: Physical capital is the stock of equipment, buildings, and other assets that are used in production. Financial capital includes the financial resources used to purchase the physical capital and afford other expenditures that facilitate business.

Front: Explain the relation between the demand for physical capital and the demand for financial capital.
Back: The firm's demand for financial capital is determined by its demand for physical capital. The firm must plan to borrow (and save) the amounts sufficient to cover expenditures on the factors of production and other costs.

Front: Explain the role of the present value technique in determining the demand for capital.
Back: The firm must calculate the present value of future revenues in order to make the capital investment decision regarding the purchase (now) of new equipment or other productive assets.

Front: Explain the factors that influence the supply of capital.
Back: The supply of capital is determined by the amount that people and firms are currently saving. Therefore the factors that influence saving, such as interest rates, expected inflation, expected future income, and current income, all contribute to changes in the supply of capital.

Front: What is the difference between renewable and non-renewable natural resources? What do their supply curves look like?
Back: Renewable resources are those that are naturally replenished by nature. Non-renewable resources are not. Therefore, the supply of renewable natural resources is fixed (land, for instance) and so the supply curve is perfectly inelastic. The supply of nonrenewable natural resources is perfectly elastic at a price that is equal to the discounted value of next year's expected price. This is because owners would refrain from selling their stock if they would make more by selling it next year (instead of making interest on the amount of the current receipt).

Front: Explain the difference between economic rent and opportunity costs.
Back: Opportunity costs measure the costs associated with forgone opportunities as capital (material and human capital) is employed in one project and therefore not available for others.

Front: What is the substitution effect of labor?
Back: This describes the tendency of people to work more and sacrifice their leisure time as wage rates increase.

Front: What is the income effect of labor?
Back: This describes the tendency of people to take more leisure time as wages (and income) increase.

Front: What are the four phases of the business cycle?
Back: The four phases of the business cycle are: NLN1. Recession NLN2. Recessionary trough NLN3. Expansion NLN4. Peak

Front: Define aggregate hours.
Back: This is the sum of hours worked by all workers during the course of the year. It can also refer to total hours worked by those in a particular sector or group, depending on the case analysis.

Front: Define real wage rate.
Back: This is the wage compensation rate adjusted for inflation.

Front: List the three types of unemployment.
Back: 1. Frictional unemployment NLN2. Structural unemployment NLN3. Cyclical unemployment

Front: What is frictional unemployment?
Back: Frictional unemployment, sometimes called search unemployment is characterized by the transition between jobs; it is the constant turnover as qualified workers take time to be matched to a suitable, existing job opening.

Front: What is structural unemployment?
Back: Structural unemployment results from a structural change in the economy that replaces existing jobs with ones that demand a different skill set, so that laid off workers are not qualified for the newly generated job openings.

Front: What is cyclical unemployment?
Back: Cyclical unemployment refers to unemployment that rises during contractionary periods and falls during times of expansion. Note that at levels above full capacity, negative cyclical unemployment exists, or the economy is said to be running above full employment.

Front: Explain full employment.
Back: Full employment is the economic condition in which cyclical unemployment is zero. Since there is still structural and frictional employment in this circumstance, there is still some level of unemployment when the economy is at full employment. Also, according to the Phillips Curve, the ideal full employment is determined by the rate of inflation.

Front: Explain the natural rate of unemployment.
Back: The natural rate of unemployment is the rate of UNemployment when the economy is at full employment. It represents the hypothetical unemployment rate consistent with aggregate production at the “long-run” level, and so it is determined by the economy's capacity for production, also called the “supply side”.

Front: Describe the relation between the consumer price index (CPI) and the inflation rate.
Back: To get the inflation rate, calculate the percentage change in the CPI year over year.

Front: What is the consumer price index (CPI)? How do you calculate it?
Back: This is a measure used to estimate the average price of a basket of household consumer goods and services, in relation to a base price for the same basket from a prior period. The way it is calculated is by taking the ratio of the current price to the base period price and multiplying by 100.

Front: What are the main sources of consumer price index (CPI) bias?
Back: Bias arises from new goods being consumed, improved quality of basket goods and services, commodity substitution and outlet substitution.

Front: Define inflation and explain its causes.
Back: Inflation is a rise in the level of prices over a period of time. It is also a decline in the real value of money, a loss in the purchasing power of each dollar held. The inflation rate is the rate of increase of a price index (usually, the consumer price index). NLNInflation usually is the result of aggregate demand in excess of aggregate supply, pushing prices higher for scarce goods and services. High rates of inflation and hyperinflation are associated with excessive growth of the money supply.

Front: Describe the macroeconomic long-run aggregate supply curve and the factors that affect it.
Back: The long-run aggregate supply curve is vertical at potential GDP. This is because it is presumed that all prices change in concert, meaning that an increase in prices for a product would accompany a proportional change in prices of all inputs of production for that product.

Front: What factors cause movement of the macroeconomic long-run and short-run aggregate supply curve (LAS and SAS)?
Back: Any change that would affect potential real GDP would shift both the long- and short-run aggregate supply curves. Such changes would be: a change in the quantity of capital, an advance in technology, and a change in the full-employment quantity of labor.

Front: Why does the aggregate demand curve slope downward?
Back: The aggregate demand curve slopes down for two reasons: the wealth effect and the substitution effect.

Front: Explain the difference between short-run and long-run macroeconomic equilibrium.
Back: In the long-run, equilibrium occurs where the aggregate demand curve intersects the long-run aggregate supply (LAS) curve, at potential GDP, while the money wage also adjusts in the long run so that the short-run aggregate supply curve also intersects the LAS curve at the same equilibrium price level. NLNIn the short-run, equilibrium occurs where the aggregate demand curve intersects just the short-run aggregate supply curve.

Front: Describe the macroeconomic short-run aggregate supply curve and the factors that affect it.
Back: The short-run aggregate supply curve is linear because prices may increase while wages and the prices of inputs may remain constant. Thus, when facing higher prices, it is profitable for firms to increase production.

Front: What is the substitution effect of demand?
Back: The substitution effect describes the habit of people to substitute cheaper, internationally made goods when domestic price levels rise. Also, the same effect describes the tendency of people to save money when prices rise, since interest rates typically rise when prices do.

Front: What is the wealth effect of demand?
Back: When price levels rise but all else stays the same, the amount people have saved (their wealth) has lesser real value. Thus, they are encouraged to restore their wealth through further saving and decreased consumption.

Front: What factors shift the aggregate demand curve?
Back: All factors besides price level that affect people's consumption levels cause shifts in the demand curve. Such factors include: future expectations (of inflation, income, etc.), fiscal and monetary policies, and the world economy.

Front: What is M1?
Back: M1 is the measure of money including currency, traveler's checks, and checking deposits held by private businesses and individuals.

Front: What is M2?
Back: M2 is the measure of money including time deposits, savings deposits, and money market mutual funds, and similar deposits.

Front: Describe the potential problems in measuring an economy's money supply.
Back: One problem is that so much of U.S. currency is held abroad, reducing the reliability of M1. NLNAnother problem is that low fee stock and bond funds have attracted funds out of M2 components (time deposits, savings deposits, and money market mutual funds, etc.) NLNNote: Credit cards and debit cards allow people to hold less currency and keep more deposits. This in turn allows banks to create more money. The increasing use of credit cards and debit cards should thus be checked by the Fed to prevent uncontrolled growth in the money supply and unexpected inflation.

Front: List the functions of money.
Back: Money functions as: NLN1. a medium of exchange NLN2. a unit of account NLN3. a store of value.

Front: List some of the financial regulations that protect depositors.
Back: Financial regulations that protect depositors are: deposit insurance, required reserves, minimum equity reserves, and deposit and lending rules.

Front: Describe relationship between the reserve ratio, required reserves, and excess reserves.
Back: The reserve ratio is the fraction of a bank's total deposits that are held in reserves. The required reserves are the amount in deposits that must be held according to regulation; the amount is equal to total deposits multiplied by the required reserve ratio. NLNExcess reserves are those reserves held above and beyond the required reserves.

Front: How does a bank create money?
Back: Banks loan out excess reserves to create money. NLNThe total amount of money created by the banking system, given new deposits, is determined by the money multiplier and the multiplier effect. A series of steps is repeated: banks lend excess reserves (a portion of new deposits); this increases the total quantity of money in the system; this money is used and a portion is eventually deposited again; this increases the bank's required reserves and also its excess reserves (but by a smaller amount than before). This process is repeated until excess reserves are zero.

Front: Describe the intentions of the U.S. Federal Reserve in conducting monetary policy.
Back: The Fed's goals are to maintain a steady rate of inflation, full employment, a perpetually moderate business cycle, and long term economic growth. In reality, the Fed strives for these goals as best as it can, but is compelled more generally to just improve the performance of the economy.

Front: What three policy tools does the Fed use to control the quantity of money?
Back: Monetary policy implies the power to adjust the quantity of money in circulation. The three policy tools used to control the money supply are: NLNThe required reserve ratio NLNThe discount rate NLNOpen Market Operations NLNNLNNote: In the recent recession, the Federal Reserve has opened its “window” to purchasing other types of assets (some “toxic”) from banks in order facilitate lending.

Front: What is the required reserve ratio?
Back: This is the minimum percentage of deposits that a bank must hold in reserves. The Fed has the power to set the required reserve ratio for each type of deposit.

Front: How does the Fed use the discount rate in monetary policy?
Back: This is the rate at which the Fed is prepared to lend out to banks and other depositary institutions. This rate makes it easier or harder (cheaper or more expensive) for institutions to meet their reserve requirements.

Front: What are open market operations?
Back: This is the most powerful tool given to the Central bank. An open market operation is when the Federal Reserve purchases or sells a government security on the open market. When the Fed purchases a security (U.S. Treasury bill or bond) then it adds to the money in circulation.

Front: What are the assets and liabilities on the Fed's balance sheet?
Back: The Fed's assets are: gold and foreign exchange, U.S. government securities, and loans to banks. The Fed's liabilities are: Federal reserve notes in circulation, and banks' deposits.

Front: What is the monetary base?
Back: The monetary base is comprised of coins and paper money in circulation and the Fed's liabilities (all commercial banks' reserves with the central bank).

Front: What is the money multiplier?
Back: This is the mechanism used to calculate the maximum amount of money that an initial deposit can be expanded to with a given reserve ratio. It is equal to one divided by the reserve ratio (although this does not account for currency drain). The money multiplier is larger when the reserve required ratio is smaller or when less currency is in circulation.

Front: What is the relation between the monetary base, the money multiplier, and the quantity of money?
Back: The money multiplier will determine the change in the quantity of money that results from a given change in the monetary base. Remember that when a commercial bank makes additional deposits with the Fed, its increased reserve allows it to create money, and the money multiplier is used to calculate the maximum amount of money that can be created.

Front: What are the determinants of aggregate supply and demand of money? Describe the supply and demand curves.
Back: The supply of money is controlled by the central bank through its monetary policy. As a curve it is inelastic (vertical). NLNThe demand for money is dependent on interest rates. When interest rates rise, the cost of holding money (the cost of liquidity) increases, and people will instead buy assets that appreciate with price levels. When interest rates fall, people are more willing to hold money because there is less benefit to holding financial assets. Thus, the demand curve is downward sloping (relatively elastic). NLNIn macroeconomics, the supply and demand curve cross at an equilibrium rate of interest and quantity of money demanded.

Front: Describe the effects of changes in real GDP on the demand for money.
Back: An increase in real GDP is equivalent to an increase in aggregate expenditures and income. People, with higher incomes, will spend more and consequently will want to have more money on hand to finance those expenditures. This will shift out the money demand curve.

Front: Explain interest rate determination.
Back: Interest rates converge at the equilibrium point where the supply of money equals the demand for money. Each day, the supply of money is set, and the demand for money changes with the interest rate, all else being relatively constant.

Front: Describe the quantity theory of money.
Back: The quantity theory of money states that an increase in the quantity of money in circulation will bring about an equal percentage increase in prices. It is founded on the concept of the velocity of circulation, which is the number of times a dollar is used to pay for all goods and services (GDP): NLNV = PY/M, where V is velocity of money; P is prices; Y is GDP, and M is the supply of money. NLNThe equation of exchange adjusts the equation to the form: NLNMV = PY NLNThe quantity theory of money is based on the equation of exchange and the assumption that velocity and GDP are slow to change, or that V and Y are considered constant. Thus, the percentage increase in the quantity of money will equal the percentage increase in price levels.

Front: Explain the relation between the quantity theory of money and aggregate supply and demand.
Back: The quantity theory of money, or more specifically the equation of exchange, can be used to create the equation P=MV/Y. Holding the quantity of money (M) and the velocity of circulation (V) constant, this equation can be interpreted as describing the aggregate demand curve - price level (P) as a function of quantity (Y). By the same equation, an increase in the quantity of money would cause a shift in the aggregate demand curve upward by the same amount as the percentage change in the quantity of money. Then, using the aggregate supply-aggregate demand (AS-AD) model, it can be shown that the short run aggregate supply curve would eventually move upward by an equal amount in order for real GDP to remain at potential, long-run GDP. Thus, the money wage rate would also have increased by the same proportion.

Front: Explain the consequences of the Fed raising the interest rate.
Back: If the Fed were to raise interest rates, three things would happen. First, investment and consumption expenditures would decrease as people are incentivized to save. Second, the dollar rises because higher interest domestic interest rates would increase demand for the dollar. Finally, a multiplier process unfolds in which the decreased expenditures, on top of the decrease in exports (due to the more expensive dollar), would slow real GDP growth and inflation.

Front: What is the equation of exchange?
Back: The equation of exchange states that MV=PY. In plain English, it says that the quantity of money (M) multiplied by the velocity of circulation (V) equals GDP, which is price level (P) multiplied by the quantity of production (Y).

Front: Describe the effects of financial innovation on the demand for money.
Back: Some financial innovations that have changed the demand for money (and currency held) are: ATMs, credit cards, debit cards, internet banking, online bill paying, and daily interest checking deposits.

Front: What are the effects of inflation on economic activity?
Back: The effects of inflation are that it increases risk, distorts prices, and reduces output.

Front: What is the difference between inflation and the price level?
Back: Inflation is the rate at which a price level increases year over year.

Front: Explain the evolution of demand-pull inflation.
Back: Demand-pull inflation starts with an increase in aggregate demand, which would occur if the Fed lowered interest rates or if the government increased spending. Then, using the AS-AD model, the short-run aggregate supply curve would move upwards so that its point of intersection with the new aggregate demand curve would coincide with the long-run supply curve, which is constant at real, potential GDP. Thus, the increase in aggregate demand pulls the price level upwards in the long-run.

Front: Explain the evolution of cost-push inflation.
Back: This is when inflation results from an initial increase in costs of production, which typically occur in the form of higher money wage rates or an increase in the money prices of raw materials, such as oil. The increase in costs moves the short-run aggregate supply curve leftward (and upward) to reflect these higher costs. NLNThe new intersection point with the aggregate demand curve, as indicated in the AS-AD model, is at a real GDP less than the potential GDP. Thus, unemployment rises above its natural rate. NLNThis would typically induce a public outcry that would encourage a response by the Fed or government to increase aggregate demand, moving equilibrium back to the full employment level of real GDP, but at a much higher price level.

Front: Describe the difference between anticipated and unanticipated inflation.
Back: Unanticipated inflation unexpectedly reduces purchasing power and the real value of money over time. Any income to be received (an annuity, for example) then has a lower present value, after the cash flows are discounted. NLNAnticipated inflation is accounted for in financial transactions so that a stream of income maintains its real value. This can be done using a variable-rate contract or by demanding hire prices on fixed rate contracts.

Front: Explain the effects of unanticipated inflation in the market for financial capital.
Back: Unanticipated inflation leads to the redistribution of income and too much or too little lending or borrowing. For instance, if banks have lent out at a given rate, and then inflation increases, the money being repaid to lenders is worth less than would have been expected. In this case, the borrowers gain at the expense of lenders. At the same time, borrowers will have wished they had borrowed more, and lenders will have wished they had lent out less.

Front: What is the impact of unanticipated inflation on the labor market?
Back: Remember that wage rates are set to reflect the expected amount of inflation. That is, aggregate demand is expected to rise by some amount and so the SAS curve is set to that level by raising wages.  If inflation is any more or less than that expected rate, the demand curve will intersect the short-run aggregate supply curve to the right or left of potential GDP, which is the GDP at full employment and LAS (in the AD-AS model). Depending on whether aggregate demand increases by more or less than expected,  demand-pull or cost-push inflation will result.

Front: Describe the short-run Phillips curve.
Back: The short-run Phillips curve shows the relationship between inflation and unemployment when either the expected inflation rate and the natural employment rate are given (all points are on the curve).

Front: Describe the long-run Phillips curve.
Back: The long-run Phillips curve shows the relationship between inflation and unemployment when the actual inflation rate is in fact the expected rate. It is a vertical line, meaning that at any anticipated rate of inflation the economy can still function at full employment. Note that this is consistent with the AD-AS model, when the SAS curve moves upward in anticipation of upward shifts in the demand curve (that result from inflation).

Front: Describe what happens when inflation increases to a new expected rate, using short-run and long-run Phillips curves.
Back: First, the unexpected change in inflation will result in a movement along the short-run Phillips curve, and the unemployment rate will fall (to point B). Then, as this new rate of inflation becomes the anticipated rate of inflation, the short-run Phillips curve will shift upwards until the unemployment is again at the natural rate (point C).

Front: How do changes in the natural rate of unemployment affect the short-run and long-run Phillips curve?
Back: Changes in the natural rate of employment shift both the short-run and long-run Phillips curves.

Front: Explain the relation among inflation, nominal interest rates, and real interest rates.
Back: At equilibrium, the nominal interest rate will equal the real interest rate plus the expected inflation rate.

Front: What are the adverse consequences of excessive levels of anticipated inflation?
Back: First, transaction costs increase because the velocity of circulation increases. People expect that their money will not hold its value so they spend it quickly. This also diverts those money resources from producing goods and services that would increase GDP. NLNSecondly, tax effects seriously diminish the after-tax real interest rate, because people must account for inflation after taxes. NLNFinally, the increased uncertainty that accompanies high rates of anticipated inflation can deter investors and hamper long-term planning.

Front: What are the supply-side effects of income tax on employment and potential GDP?
Back: Workers will be discouraged to work less because they will earn less (the substitution effect). Potential GDP will fall with employment.

Front: What is the Laffer curve?
Back: A Laffer curve illustrates the relationship between the tax rate and tax revenues. As the tax rate increases from 0 to 100 percent, revenue increases from zero to a maximum and then falls back to zero.

Front: What equation describes the relationship between government spending and investment?
Back: Investment is equal to private saving plus the government surplus (deficit).

Front: What are the generational effects of fiscal policy?
Back: Government-issued debt and government spending is financed by taxes and other government collections (such as social security). When the government creates liabilities, it is the burden of future generations to pay off those liabilities through taxes and other government receipts.

Front: What is the generation imbalance?
Back: The generation imbalance is the distribution of fiscal imbalances among current and future generations.

Front: What is an automatic stabilizer in regards to fiscal policy.
Back: An automatic stabilizer is a fiscal policy measure that is triggered by the state of the economy. It acts to mitigate swings in the economic cycle.

Front: What is the tax multiplier?
Back: This is the multiplier process in which a decrease in taxes leads to a compounded increase in aggregate expenditure.

Front: What is the government purchases multiplier?
Back: This is the multiplier process in which an increase in government spending leads to a compounded increase in aggregate expenditure.

Front: What is the balanced budget multiplier?
Back: This is the multiplier process in which a change in government purchases, combined with a simultaneous and off-setting change in taxes, leads to increased aggregate demand but leaves the budget balance unchanged.

Front: Explain the crowding-out effect.
Back: The crowding-out effect is when the government deficit is so large that it pushes up real interest rates; so-called government dissaving requires selling bonds at higher rates. This effectively “crowds-out” other, less attractive investments and increases private saving. This suggests that fiscal policy is less effective than Keynesians believe (it counteracts the intentions of expansionary or restrictive changes).

Front: Describe and illustrate the use of automatic stabilizers in fiscal policy.
Back: Automatic stabilizers are devices used to stabilize real GDP without explicit action by the government. Automatic fiscal policy is not hampered by the three time lags (recognition, law-making, and impact). NLNOn the revenues side of the budget, induced taxes vary with real GDP. Tax receipts rise and fall with real GDP. NLNOn the expenditures side of the budget, needs-tested spending increases money transfers to eligible individuals when the economy is in a recession; the opposite is true in periods of expansion. NLNFor example, in a recession, unemployment compensation increases with unemployment (needs-tested spending). Meanwhile, tax receipts will fall with real GDP (induced taxes).  This works to increase the budget deficit, acting like an expansionary change.

Front: Explain the process by which a Keynesian fiscal policy would push an economy back to full employment.
Back: The government should adopt an expansionary fiscal policy, increasing deficit spending, in order to raise aggregate demand. Tax reductions and spending on public works are two methods of government spending.

Front: How would a restrictive fiscal policy be used according to Keynes?
Back: According to the Keynesian model, reduced government spending and higher taxes would lower aggregate demand and consequently would lower prices and reduce output.

Front: Explain the impact of timing on planned fiscal policies.
Back: By the time there is sufficient indication to warrant a change in fiscal policy, the opportunity for a preventive response is past.  Moreover, there is a lag between when the need is recognized and when an appropriate policy is implemented. Then, there is a lag as the policy takes effect. It is widely held that the impact of planned fiscal policy is so delayed that it amplifies the natural corrective action of the economy and in so doing pushes the economy past equilibrium in its recovery.

Front: Which is of greater magnitude, the tax multiplier or the government purchases multiplier?
Back: The government purchases multiplier is greater, because a portion of tax cuts are initially saved according to people's marginal propensity to consume (and save). Meanwhile, the whole amount of government expenditures immediately contributes to GDP.

Front: What is the fiscal imbalance?
Back: The fiscal imbalance is the present value of the government's commitments to pay benefits minus the present value of current and future tax revenues.

Front: What are the U.S. Federal Reserve's principle and intermediate goals?
Back: The Fed's primary goal is to maintain price level stability. Intermediate goals are to keep real GDP at or around potential GDP and to help maintain sustainable real GDP growth.

Front: Explain the New Classical economic approach to an expansionary fiscal policy.
Back: New Classical economists suggest that the effect of government dissaving will be interpreted as a future tax liability, and so taxpayers will restrain consumption, increasing private saving, in anticipation of this liability. NLNNLNNote: This is called the Ricardo-Barro effect when a government budget deficit has no effect on the real interest rate or investment.

Front: Explain the Supply Side economic approach to an expansionary fiscal policy.
Back: Supply side economists argue that fiscal policy changes should reduce taxes on wages and investment, thereby increasing the propensity to work and invest. This would increase aggregate supply of capital and labor and thus increase output in the long run.

Front: Describe the difference between an activist and a non-activist strategy for stabilization activity.
Back: Activists argue that discretionary economic policy can stabilize the economy. Non-activists, on the other hand, argue that a steady growth in the money supply and a balanced federal budget are more likely to temper inflation and provide lasting economic stability.

Front: Explain fixed-rule and feedback-rule monetary policies.
Back: A fixed-rule policy is one that should be pursued regardless of the state of the economy. NLNA feedback-rule policy is one taken in response to the state of the economy.

Front: Describe fixed-rule and feedback-rule policies aimed at responding to a productivity shock (a reduction in long-run aggregate supply).
Back: A monetarists' fixed-rule policy is to maintain a constant supply of money; using an AD-AS curve, when a productivity shock occurs - decreasing long-run aggregate supply (LAS) - and aggregate demand remains unchanged, price level increases and real GDP falls. No action by the Fed is taken. NLNNLNFeedback-rule policies that the Fed can pursue will either increase or decrease aggregate demand via a change in money supply. The only effective policy given a productivity shock is to decrease the money supply so that aggregate demand falls, stabilizing price levels. Remember that LAS is vertical, so no policy can effectively stabilize GDP – the economy does not have the capacity to produce more.

Front: Describe fixed-rule and feedback-rule policies aimed at responding to a cost-push inflation shock (reduction in short-term aggregate supply).
Back: A monetarists' fixed-rule policy is to maintain a constant supply of money; using an AD-AS curve, when a temporary supply shock occurs, moving the short-term supply curve to the left, the result is a decrease in real GDP and an increase in price levels, an effect called stagflation. The Fed takes no action; the economy is in recession (producing at less than full capacity) until the inflation shock dissipates. NLNNLNA feedback-rule to stabilize GDP would increase the money supply in order to stimulate aggregate demand. This would push the AD curve to the right along the affected SAS curve until real GDP returns to its original level. This increases the price level further, an effect called cost-push inflation. NLNA feedback-rule to stabilize price levels would decrease the money supply, reducing aggregate demand. This further reduces real GDP in order to keep price levels constant.

Front: Explain how the credibility of monetary policy can influence the policy's effectiveness.
Back: When an inflation reduction is announced and credible, the rate of inflation can be pushed down with no accompanying recession or increase in unemployment. This is because the “built-in inflation” caused by wage increases is forced to coincide with moderate growth in aggregate demand, such that the point of equilibrium is on the long-run supply curve (where real GDP is at capacity). Also, the short-run Phillips curve moves downward when inflation and wage growth is expected to slow; so at the new expected rate of inflation, the economy remains at full employment.

Front: What is the new monetarist rule?
Back: The McCallum rule is considered to be the new monetarist rule, and it provides a theorem for determining a target monetary base for the Fed.

Front: What is the new Keynesian rule?
Back: The Taylor rule is considered the new Keynesian rule, and it is a popular formula for determining a new federal funds rate in response to divergences of actual inflation rates from target inflation rates and actual Gross Domestic Product (GDP) from potential GDP.

Front: What are explicit costs?
Back: Explicit costs are measurable cash flows for operating expenses.

Front: What are implicit costs?
Back: Implicit costs measure the opportunity costs of using a firm's assets (e.g. equipment and labor).

Front: Differentiate between economic profit and accounting profit.
Back: Economic profit includes both explicit and implicit costs for a firm. Accounting profit ignores implicit costs. Accounting profits are generally higher than economic profits because they do not account for opportunity costs. When the firm's revenues are just equal to its costs (explicit an implicit, including the normal rate of return) economic profits will be zero.

Front: What are sunk costs?
Back: Sunk costs are costs that have already been incurred in prior investments. Sunk costs should not influence new economic decision making.

Front: What is the difference between financial reporting and financial statement analysis?
Back: Financial reporting is how companies provide information about their performance, financial position, and changes in financial position. Financial statement analysis is the process of using that information, together with other research, to make intelligent investment decisions.

Front: What is the key role of the income statement?
Back: The income statement describes a company's performance over a period of time.

Front: What is the key role of the balance sheet?
Back: The balance sheet indicates a company's financial position at a given point in time.

Front: What is the key role of the cash flow statement?
Back: The cash flow statement, like the income statement, indicates a company's performance over a period of time.

Front: What is the key role of the statement of changes in owners' equity?
Back: The statement of changes in owners' equity contains additional information regarding the changes in a company's financial position.

Front: What is the objective of audits of financial statements?
Back: Financial reports are typically required to be audited by an independent accounting firm in order that the auditor may verify that the financial statements are prepared in accordance with the applicable financial framework.

Front: What are other sources of information besides annual financial statements that analysts use in financial analysis?
Back: Companies also provide useful information in supplementary schedules, in the management's discussion and analysis (MD&A), and in footnote disclosures.

Front: What is depreciation?
Back: When equipment is used and provides revenue over several periods, its cost must also be spread over multiple future periods; depreciation is this process of spreading cost over multiple periods.

Front: What is cost of goods sold?
Back: Cost of goods sold is the expense to inventory when products are sold. It is the cost of producing those goods or services.

Front: What is accrual accounting?
Back: In accrual accounting, expenses are recorded when incurred, not when paid, and revenue is recorded when earned, not when received. NLNNote: Each type of accrual involves an originating entry and at least one entry for adjustment at a later date or dates.

Front: Accumulated depreciation is an example of what type of account?
Back: Accumulated depreciation is a contra asset account (to equipment accounts usually).

Front: What is the accounting equation in its basic form?
Back: Assets = Liabilities + Owners' equity

Front: What is the accounting equation in its expanded form?
Back: Assets = Liabilities + Contributed Capital + Beginning Retained Earnings + Revenue - Expenses - Dividends

Front: What are the financial statement elements?
Back: The five financial statement elements are: assets, liabilities, equity, revenue, and expense.

Front: Describe the flow of information in an accounting system.
Back: Transactions are first recorded in journal entries and adjusting entries by date. Then, a general ledger is used to organize those entries by account, typically using T-accounts. The ledger is used to create a trial balance or adjusted trial balance, both of which list account balances at a particular point in time. Finally, financial statements are prepared using the account totals from an adjusted trial balance.

Front: What is the left-hand side of a T-account entry called?
Back: A debit.

Front: What is the right-hand side of a T-account entry called?
Back: A credit.

Front: What is the US standard-setting body?
Back: The U.S. Financial Accounting Standards Board (FASB)

Front: What is the international standard-setting body?
Back: The International Accounting Standards Board (IASB).

Front: What are the ongoing barriers to developing one universally accepted set of financial reporting standards?
Back: Barriers to convergence of financial standards are: political pressures and cultural differences, different views of priorities and objectives, as well as differences in approaches to valuation, standard-setting, and measurement.

Front: What are the fundamental principles of financial statements?
Back: Financial statements must abide by the fundamental principles of fair presentation, going concern, accrual basis, consistency, and materiality.

Front: What are the reporting standards promoted by the IASB called?
Back: The International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS).

Front: What are the reporting standards promoted by the FASB called?
Back: The U.S. Generally Accepted Accounting Principles (US GAAP).

Front: The Financial Accounting Standards Board (FASB) states that financial statements should disclose sufficient information to illustrate:
Back: 1. How the firm earns and spends money. NLN2. The firm's borrowing and debt repayment activities. NLN3. The firm's ownership position (sale and buyback of its own securities). NLN4. Dividends and other cash distributions.NLN5. Other factors affecting liquidity and solvency.

Front: What are the three primary characteristics of an effective financial reporting framework?
Back: The three characteristics are: transparency, comprehensiveness, and consistency.

Front: What are the three inherent constraints to an effective financial reporting framework?
Back: The three primary constraints are: timeliness, benefit versus cost, and balance between qualitative characteristics.

Front: What are the required financial statements according to IAS No. 1?
Back: The required financial statements according to IFRS are: the balance sheet, the income statement, the statement of changes in equity, the cash flow statement, and notes (comprising a summary of significant accounting policies and other explanatory notes).

Front: What are the four principal qualitative characteristics that make financial information useful, according to the IASB Framework?
Back: The four principles of useful financial information are: understandability, relevance, reliability, and comparability.

Front: What is net revenue?
Back: Net revenue is revenue after adjustments for estimated returns, amounts unlikely to be collected, and similar charges.

Front: What is the multi-step format of an income statement?
Back: A multi-step format includes a gross profit subtotal in the income statement. The single-step format does not.

Front: What is the completed contract method of revenue recognition?
Back: The completed contract method stipulates that the firm does not report revenue until the contract is finished.

Front: What is the percentage-of-completion method?
Back: The percentage-of-completion method stipulates that in each accounting period the company estimates the percentage of total contract work completed in the period, and counts an equal percentage of total contract revenue in its income statement.

Front: Between the completed contract and percentage-of-completion methods, which is more conservative?
Back: The completed contract method is more conservative because it recognizes revenue later.

Front: What is the installment method of reporting revenue according to U.S. GAAP?
Back: According to U.S. GAAP, the installment method stipulates that all revenue is recognized at the date of sale, but that the gain is held in a deferred gain account and recognized per installment. The profit recognized in any installment is apportioned from the cash receipt using the ratio of profit to sales value.

Front: What is the installment method of reporting revenue according to IFRS?
Back: According to IFRS, the installment method stipulates that revenue should only be reported to the extent cash is received, and profit recognized per payment is apportioned from the cash receipt using the ratio of profit to sales value.

Front: What is the cost recovery method of revenue recognition?
Back: The cost recovery method stipulates that the company would not recognize profit attributable to any payment until the cash amounts paid by the buyer exceed all the seller's costs of property and sale.

Front: What is the matching principle?
Back: The matching principle stipulates that a company should directly match its expenses, such as cost of goods sold, with associated revenues in the same period.

Front: How are doubtful accounts, in which receivables are uncollectable, accounted for using generally accepted accounting principles?
Back: According to the matching principle, companies are required to record an estimated amount of revenue that will be uncollectible in the period. This is usually based on previous experience and based on a percentage of total sales.

Front: How are warranties expensed by companies according to generally accepted accounting principles?
Back: Under the matching principle, companies are required to record an estimated expense associated with warranties issued in the period of sale; companies must then update the expense over the life of the warranties as they are redeemed.

Front: What is the difference between depreciation and amortization?
Back: Depreciation is the systematic allocation of costs associated with long-lived assets in each period that those assets provide revenues. Depreciation is the term used for assets such as plant and property. NLNAmortization is the term used when the asset is intangible with a finite useful life.

Front: How are costs allocated over time for an intangible asset with an indefinite lifespan?
Back: The value of these assets is not amortized; instead, the value is tested annually for impairment and adjusted accordingly.

Front: What are the three primary methods of calculating depreciation costs?
Back: The three main methods of depreciation are: the straight-line method, the diminishing balance method (also called accelerated depreciation), and the units of production method.

Front: What is the residual value of an asset?
Back: The residual value of an asset is its salvage value, or the estimated future market value of an asset at the end of its useful life.

Front: What is the annual depreciation expense of an asset, using double declining balance method depreciation?
Back: Annual depreciation expense by this method is typically calculated by doubling the expense at the straight-line rate of depreciation, assuming the asset has no residual value (even if it will have salvage value), applying that expense to the net book value of the asset. In each successive year, the depreciation expense should again be twice the straight-line rate, using net book value (instead of total cost) and no residual value for the asset. Depreciation expense at the end of an asset's useful life should not exceed the amount required to make net book value equal to the asset's real salvage value.
